rules.recommend: Use spaced repetition (Day 1, 3, 7, 14, 30)
Practice active recall - test yourself instead of re-reading
Improve sleep to 7-8 hours for better memory consolidation

memory.explanation: Memory works in 3 stages: Encoding ‚Üí Storage ‚Üí Retrieval. Spaced repetition strengthens long-term storage, active recall improves retrieval, and sleep consolidates memories during rest.
examples: Use Anki app for automated spaced repetition
Teach concepts to others (Feynman Technique)
Create mind maps to visualize connections
Use mnemonic devices for complex information
resources: Book: 'Make It Stick' by Brown, Roediger & McDaniel

stress.diagnosis: You are experiencing exam-related stress - affects 60-70% of students

rules.recommend: Practice 4-7-8 breathing: Inhale 4 sec, Hold 7 sec, Exhale 8 sec
Use grounding technique (5-4-3-2-1): 5 things you see, 4 touch, 3 hear, 2 smell, 1 taste
Practice past papers under timed conditions to reduce fear of unknown
Regular exercise (30 min, 3x/week) reduces cortisol naturally

stress.explanation: Your body enters fight-or-flight mode when facing exams. This causes racing heart, sweaty palms, and mind going blank. Root causes include fear of failure, perfectionism, poor preparation, and past negative experiences.
examples: Before exam: 3 rounds of 4-7-8 breathing
During panic: Use 5-4-3-2-1 grounding
Daily: 10-minute meditation with Headspace app
Morning routine: 20-minute walk reduces cortisol
resources: Book: 'Why Zebras Don't Get Ulcers' by Sapolsky

procrastination.diagnosis: You are stuck in the procrastination cycle - it's about emotion regulation, not laziness

rules.recommend: Use 2-minute rule: Commit to just 2 minutes - usually leads to more
Pomodoro Technique: 25 min focus + 5 min break cycles
Break large tasks into tiny steps (chunking)
Remove phone from room and use website blockers

procrastination.explanation: Procrastination happens due to: task aversion (feels painful), perfectionism, overwhelm, instant gratification bias, and fear of failure. The cycle: Task ‚Üí Anxiety ‚Üí Temporary relief ‚Üí Guilt ‚Üí More anxiety.
examples: Set timer for 2 minutes and start easiest sub-task
Use Forest app to gamify focus time
Study buddy accountability check-ins
Implementation intention: 'At 3pm, in library, study Chapter 5'

time_management.diagnosis: You need a structured study system with clear priorities

rules.recommend: Use time blocking: Assign specific time slots to specific subjects
Apply Eisenhower Matrix: Urgent+Important = Do now, Important only = Schedule
Weekly review: Plan each Sunday for the week ahead
Do hardest subjects when energy is highest (usually morning)

time_management.explanation: Poor time management leads to cramming, incomplete understanding, and high stress. Most students FEEL busy but aren't PRODUCTIVE. A system provides clear plans, reduces stress, and ensures balanced coverage.
examples: Google Calendar with color-coded study blocks
Sunday planning: 30 min to plan week ahead
Daily top 3: Pick 3 most important tasks
Energy optimization: Hard subjects at 8am when fresh

exam_prep.diagnosis: You need a strategic, timeline-based exam prep plan

rules.recommend: Practice past papers under timed conditions (most effective prep)
Focus on high-weightage topics (80/20 rule)
Light review only, no new material - sleep by 10pm
Arrive 20 min early, do breathing exercises, avoid anxious students

exam_prep.explanation: Timeline matters: 3 months = foundation, 1 month = intensive revision, 1 week = practice & polish, 1 day = light review & mental prep. Common mistakes include cramming, passive reading, and not practicing under exam conditions.
examples: 1 week before: Complete 2-3 past papers under timed conditions
Night before: Materials ready, light review, sleep by 10pm
Exam day: Protein breakfast, arrive early, bathroom first
During exam: Read all questions first, do easy ones first
resources: Past exam papers from your institution

motivation.diagnosis: You have lost your 'why' - motivation loss is normal and fixable

rules.recommend: Reconnect with your 'why': Write down why you started and your bigger goal
Set micro-goals: 'Study 25 minutes' not 'Master this subject'
Track progress visually with habit tracker or checklist
Schedule guilt-free breaks and activities you enjoy

motivation.explanation: Motivation fades due to: no clear goals, lack of visible progress, burnout, disconnection from purpose, comparison to others. IMPORTANT: Motivation follows action, not the other way around!
examples: Morning routine: Read written goal aloud before studying
Vision board with career goals on wall
Daily win journal: Write 3 things achieved
Study group for scheduled accountability

confidence.diagnosis: Low confidence is blocking your potential - this is about mindset, not ability

rules.recommend: Adopt growth mindset: Replace 'I can't' with 'I can't YET'
Keep wins journal: Write 3 daily wins to build evidence of capability
Stop comparing to others - only compete with past you
Build confidence staircase: Start with easy problems, gradually increase difficulty

confidence.explanation: Confidence myths: Intelligence is NOT fixed - it's built through effort (neuroplasticity). Real issues: fixed mindset, comparison trap, imposter syndrome, letting one result define you. Intelligence = Effort √ó Strategy √ó Time.
examples: Morning affirmation: 'I am capable of learning anything'
Wins journal: Daily entry of one thing done well
Confidence staircase: 5 easy problems first (builds momentum)
Reframe failures: 'I learned what doesn't work'
resources: TED Talk: The Power of Believing You Can Improve

sleep.diagnosis: Poor sleep is sabotaging your study effectiveness

rules.recommend: Consistent schedule: Same bedtime and wake time (even weekends)
Digital sunset: No screens 1 hour before bed (blue light suppresses melatonin)
Write worry list before bed to empty mind
Sleep environment: Cool (18-20¬∞C), dark, quiet

sleep.explanation: During sleep, your brain: consolidates memories (short-term ‚Üí long-term), clears toxins, strengthens neural connections. One all-nighter = 40% reduction in memory formation. Poor sleep causes reduced focus, impaired problem-solving, mood issues.
examples: 10pm routine: Shower ‚Üí Read ‚Üí Lights out by 11pm
Morning sunlight exposure (resets circadian rhythm)
If can't sleep after 20 min: Get up, do boring activity, return when sleepy
No caffeine after 2pm
resources: Book: 'Why We Sleep' by Matthew Walker

focus.diagnosis: You need strategies to improve concentration and reduce distractions

rules.recommend: Use the Pomodoro Technique: 25 minutes focused work, 5 minute break
Eliminate digital distractions: Turn off phone notifications and use website blockers
Practice mindfulness meditation (10 min/day) to improve attention control
Prioritize sleep - even one hour more can dramatically improve focus
Create a dedicated study space with minimal distractions

focus.explanation: Focus is the ability to direct attention to a single task while filtering out distractions. It depends on your prefrontal cortex, which is affected by stress, sleep, and environment. Research shows focused work sessions (25-90 min) with breaks are more effective than marathon sessions.
examples: Use forest/pomodoro apps to gamify focus time
Study in library instead of dorm room
Schedule difficult tasks for your peak energy time (morning for most people)
Use background music (binaural beats, lo-fi) if it helps you concentrate
Practice single-tasking: close all tabs except the one you're working on
resources: Book: Deep Work by Cal Newport

high_stress_to_low_focus.explanation: High stress impairs prefrontal cortex function, reducing focus ability

poor_sleep_to_weak_memory.explanation: Sleep deprivation prevents memory consolidation during REM and deep sleep

low_motivation_to_procrastination.explanation: Low motivation increases likelihood of task avoidance

exam_anxiety_to_stress.explanation: Exam anxiety triggers physiological stress response
